description: From Middle English unbolde, unbald, from Old English unbeald (“unbold, unconfident, irresolute”), from Proto-Germanic *unbalþaz (“unbold”), equivalent to un- +‎ bold. Cognate with Old High German unbald (“discouraged”).

adjectives.description: unbold (comparative more unbold, superlative most unbold)

verbs.description: unbold (third-person singular simple present unbolds, present participle unbolding, simple past and past participle unbolded)

entries.meaning: (typography, transitive) To change (text) from a bold typeface to a non-bolded typeface.
